title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: goal guide help get contributing qtkit quickly possible. guide divided two main pieces: Filing bug report feature request issue. Suggesting change via pull request. Please note qtkit released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: filing issue, important thing include minimal reproducible example can quickly verify problem, figure fix . three things need include make example reproducible: required packages, data, code. Packages loaded top script, ’s easy see ones example needs. easiest way include data use dput() generate R code recreate . example, recreate mtcars dataset R, ’d perform following steps: Run dput(mtcars) R Copy output reproducible script, type mtcars <- paste. even better can create data.frame() just handful rows columns still illustrates problem. Spend little bit time ensuring code easy others read: make sure ’ve used spaces variable names concise, informative use comments indicate problem lies best remove everything related problem. shorter code , easier understand. can check actually made reproducible example starting fresh R session pasting script . (Unless ’ve specifically asked , please don’t include output sessionInfo().)

title: Contributing to qtkit development
text: contribute change qtkit, follow steps: Create branch git make changes. Push branch github issue pull request (PR). Discuss pull request. Iterate either accept PR decide ’s good fit qtkit. steps described detail . ’re familiar git github, please start reading: https://r-pkgs.org/software-development-practices.html Pull requests evaluated seven point checklist: Motivation. pull request clearly concisely motivate need change. Unfortunately neither Winston much time work qtkit days, need describe problem show pull request solves concisely possible. Also include motivation NEWS new release qtkit comes ’s easy users see ’s changed. Add item top file use markdown formatting. news item end (@yourGithubUsername, #the_issue_number). related changes. submit pull request, please check make sure haven’t accidentally included unrelated changes. make harder see exactly ’s changed, evaluate unexpected side effects. PR corresponds git branch, expect submit multiple changes make sure create multiple branches. multiple changes depend , start first one don’t submit others first one processed. Use tidyverse coding style. Please follow official tidyverse style. Maintaining consistent style across whole code base makes much easier jump code. ’re modifying existing qtkit code doesn’t follow style guide, separate pull request fix style greatly appreciated. ’re adding new parameters new function, ’ll also need document roxygen2. Make sure re-run devtools::document() code submitting. fixing bug adding new feature non-graphical function, please add testthat unit test. fixing bug visual output, please add visual test. (Instructions follow soon) ’re adding new graphical feature, please add short example appropriate function. seems like lot work don’t worry pull request isn’t perfect. ’s learning process members qtkit team hand help . pull request (“PR”) process, unless ’ve submitted past ’s unlikely pull request accepted . PRs require review approval least one member qtkit development team merge.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jerid Francom. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Francom J (2024). qtkit: Quantitative Text Kit. R package version 1.0.0, https://cran.r-project.org/package=qtkit.
code: @Manual{,   title = {qtkit: Quantitative Text Kit},   author = {Jerid Francom},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://cran.r-project.org/package=qtkit}, }

title: Quantitative Text Kit
text: goal qtkit provide support package textbook “Introduction Quantitative Text Analysis Linguistics: Reproducible Research using R”. contains functions collecting manipulating data datasets, documentation, assorted tasks associated quantitative text analysis R.

title: Quantitative Text Kit
text: can install released version qtkit CRAN : development version qtkit GitHub can installed : load package : Please consult package documentation information.
code: install.packages("qtkit") install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("qtalr/qtkit") library(qtkit)

what: Add package to BibTeX file — add_pkg_to_bib
title: Add package to BibTeX file — add_pkg_to_bib
text: function adds package BibTeX file. uses knitr::write_bib function write package name file.

title: Add package to BibTeX file — add_pkg_to_bib
code: add_pkg_to_bib(pkg_name, bib_file = "packages.bib")

title: Add package to BibTeX file — add_pkg_to_bib
text: pkg_name name package add BibTeX file. bib_file name BibTeX file write .

title: Add package to BibTeX file — add_pkg_to_bib
code: my_bib_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib") add_pkg_to_bib("dplyr", my_bib_file) readLines(my_bib_file) |> cat(sep = "\n") #> @Manual{R-base, #>   title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing}, #>   author = {{R Core Team}}, #>   organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing}, #>   address = {Vienna, Austria}, #>   year = {2024}, #>   url = {https://www.R-project.org/}, #> } #>  #> @Manual{R-dplyr, #>   title = {dplyr: A Grammar of Data Manipulation}, #>   author = {Hadley Wickham and Romain François and Lionel Henry and Kirill Müller and Davis Vaughan}, #>   year = {2023}, #>   note = {R package version 1.1.4}, #>   url = {https://dplyr.tidyverse.org}, #> } #>  #> @Manual{R-qtkit, #>   title = {qtkit: Quantitative Text Kit}, #>   author = {Jerid Francom}, #>   year = {2024}, #>   note = {R package version 1.0.0}, #>   url = {https://cran.r-project.org/package=qtkit}, #> } #>

what: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: function calculates various association metrics (PMI, Dice's Coefficient, G-score) bigrams given corpus.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
code: calc_assoc_metrics(   data,   doc_index,   token_index,   type,   association = "all",   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: data data frame containing corpus. doc_index Column 'data' represents document index. token_index Column 'data' represents token index. type Column 'data' represents tokens terms. association character vector specifying metrics calculate. Can combination 'pmi', 'dice_coeff', 'g_score', ''. Default ''. verbose logical value indicating whether keep intermediate probability columns. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
text: data frame one row per bigram columns calculated metric.

title: Calculate Association Metrics for Bigrams — calc_assoc_metrics
code: data_path <- system.file("extdata", "bigrams_data.rds", package = "qtkit") data <- readRDS(data_path)  calc_assoc_metrics(data, doc_index, token_index, type) #>        y     x       pmi dice_coeff    g_score #> 1  word2 word1 1.8787708  0.7272727 -0.5191244 #> 2  word2 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 3  word2 word3 0.7801586  0.4363636 -1.6177367 #> 4  word2 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 5  word2 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 6  word3 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 7  word3 word2 1.4733057  0.8727273 -0.2314424 #> 8  word3 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 9  word3 word4 0.3746934  0.3636364 -2.0232018 #> 10 word3 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 11 word4 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 12 word4 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 13 word4 word3 1.0678406  0.7272727 -0.6369075 #> 14 word4 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 15 word4 word5 0.7801586  0.4363636 -1.6177367 #> 16 word5 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 17 word5 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 18 word5 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 19 word5 word4 1.4733057  0.8727273 -0.2314424 #> 20 word5 word5      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 21 word6 word1      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 22 word6 word2      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 23 word6 word3      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 24 word6 word4      -Inf  0.0000000       -Inf #> 25 word6 word5 1.8787708  0.7272727 -0.5191244

what: Dispersion and frequency functions These functions are for internal use only. — calc_rf
title: Dispersion and frequency functions These functions are for internal use only. — calc_rf
text: used calc_type_metrics function. Includes dispersion measures: calc_df() Document Frequency 'DF', calc_idf() Inverse Document Frequency 'IDF', calc_dp() Gries' Deviation Proportions 'DP' functions. Frequency measures include: calc_rf() calc_orf(). Takes term-document matrix (TDM) input returns respective dispersion metrics type TDM.

title: Dispersion and frequency functions These functions are for internal use only. — calc_rf
code: calc_rf(tdm)

what: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
text: function calculates type metrics tokenized text data.

title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
code: calc_type_metrics(data, type, document, frequency = NULL, dispersion = NULL)

title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
text: data data frame containing tokenized text data type variable data contains type (e.g., term, lemma) analyze. document variable data contains document IDs. frequency character vector indicating frequency metrics use. NULL (default), type n returned. options: '', 'rf' calculates relative frequency, 'orf' calculates observed relative frequency. Can specify multiple options: c("rf", "orf"). dispersion character vector indicating dispersion metrics use. NULL (default), type n returned. options: '', 'df' calculates Document Frequency. 'idf' calculates Inverse Document Frequency. 'dp' calculates Gries' Deviation Proportions. Can specify multiple options: c("df", "idf").

title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
text: data frame columns: type: unique types input data. n: frequency type across document. Optionally (based frequency dispersion arguments): rf: relative frequency type across document. orf: observed relative frequency (per 100) type across document. df: document frequency type. idf: inverse document frequency type. dp: Gries' Deviation Proportions type.

title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
text: Gries, Stefan Th. (2023). Statistical Methods Corpus Linguistics. Readings Corpus Linguistics: Teaching Research Guide Scholars Nigeria Beyond, pp. 78-114.

title: Calculate Type Metrics for Text Data — calc_type_metrics
code: data_path <- system.file("extdata", "types_data.rds", package = "qtkit") data <- readRDS(data_path) calc_type_metrics(   data = data,   type = type,   document = document,   frequency = c("rf", "orf"),   dispersion = c("df", "idf") ) #> # A tibble: 5 × 6 #>   type      n    rf   orf    df   idf #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> <dbl> #> 1 A        20   0.2    20     3     0 #> 2 B        20   0.2    20     3     0 #> 3 C        20   0.2    20     3     0 #> 4 D        20   0.2    20     3     0 #> 5 E        20   0.2    20     3     0

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: function takes data frame creates data dictionary. data dictionary includes variable name, human-readable name, variable type, description. model specified, function uses OpenAI's API generate information based characteristics data frame.

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
code: create_data_dictionary(   data,   file_path,   model = NULL,   sample_n = 5,   grouping = NULL,   force = FALSE )

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: data data frame create data dictionary . file_path file path save data dictionary . model ID OpenAI chat completion models use generating descriptions (see openai::list_models()). NULL (default), scaffolding data dictionary created. sample_n number rows sample data frame use input model. Default NULL. grouping character vector column names group sampling rows data frame model. Default NULL. force TRUE, overwrite file file_path already exists. Default FALSE.

title: Create Data Dictionary — create_data_dictionary
text: data frame containing variable name, human-readable name, variable type, description variable input data frame.

title: Create data origin file — create_data_origin
text: Data frame attributes data origin, written CSV file optionally returned.

title: Create data origin file — create_data_origin
code: create_data_origin(file_path, return = FALSE, force = FALSE)

title: Create data origin file — create_data_origin
text: file_path File path data origin file saved. return Logical value indicating whether data origin returned. force Logical value indicating whether overwrite file already exists.

title: Create data origin file — create_data_origin
text: data frame containing data origin information.

title: Create data origin file — create_data_origin
code: tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") create_data_origin(tmp_file) #> Data origin file created at `file_path`. read.csv(tmp_file) #>                 attribute #> 1           Resource name #> 2             Data source #> 3     Data sampling frame #> 4 Data collection date(s) #> 5             Data format #> 6             Data schema #> 7                 License #> 8             Attribution #>                                                 description #> 1                                 The name of the resource. #> 2                                            URL, DOI, etc. #> 3         Language, language variety, modality, genre, etc. #> 4                         The dates the data was collected. #> 5                             .txt, .csv, .xml, .html, etc. #> 6 Relationships between data elements: files, folders, etc. #> 7                                     CC BY, CC BY-SA, etc. #> 8                                     Citation information.

what: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
title: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
text: function identifies outliers numeric variable data.frame using interquartile range (IQR) method.

title: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
code: find_outliers(data, variable_name)

title: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
text: data data.frame object. variable_name symbol representing numeric variable data.

title: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
text: data.frame containing outliers variable_name. outliers found, function returns NULL. function also prints diagnostic information variable number outliers found.

title: Identify Outliers in a Numeric Variable — find_outliers
code: data(mtcars) find_outliers(mtcars, mpg) #> Variable name: mpg #> Q1: 15.425 Q3: 22.8 IQR: 7.375 #> Upper fence: 33.8625 Lower fence: 4.3625 #> Number of outliers: 1 #>                 mpg cyl disp hp drat    wt qsec vs am gear carb #> Toyota Corolla 33.9   4 71.1 65 4.22 1.835 19.9  1  1    4    1 find_outliers(mtcars, wt) #> Variable name: wt #> Q1: 2.58125 Q3: 3.61 IQR: 1.02875 #> Upper fence: 5.153125 Lower fence: 1.038125 #> Number of outliers: 3 #>                      mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb #> Cadillac Fleetwood  10.4   8  472 205 2.93 5.250 17.98  0  0    3    4 #> Lincoln Continental 10.4   8  460 215 3.00 5.424 17.82  0  0    3    4 #> Chrysler Imperial   14.7   8  440 230 3.23 5.345 17.42  0  0    3    4

what: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
title: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
text: Possible file types include .zip, .gz, .tar, .tgz

title: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
code: get_archive_data(url, target_dir, force = FALSE, confirmed = FALSE)

title: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
text: url character vector representing full url compressed file target_dir directory archive file downloaded force optional argument forcefully overwrites existing data confirmed TRUE, user confirmed permission use data. FALSE, function prompt user confirm permission. Setting TRUE useful reproducible workflows.

title: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
text: NULL, archive file unarchived target directory

title: Download an archive file and unarchive its contents — get_archive_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "data") url <-  "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/qtalr/qtkit/main/inst/extdata/test_data.zip" get_archive_data(  url = url,  target_dir = data_dir,  confirmed = TRUE) } # }

what: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: Retrieves works Project Gutenberg based specified criteria saves data CSV file. function wrapper gutenbergr package.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
code: get_gutenberg_data(   target_dir,   lcc_subject,   birth_year = NULL,   death_year = NULL,   n_works = 100,   force = FALSE,   confirmed = FALSE )

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: target_dir directory CSV file saved. lcc_subject character vector specifying Library Congress Classification (LCC) subjects filter works. birth_year optional integer specifying minimum birth year authors include. death_year optional integer specifying maximum death year authors include. n_works integer specifying number works retrieve. Default 100. force logical value indicating whether overwrite existing data already exists. confirmed TRUE, user confirmed permission use data. FALSE, function prompt user confirm permission. Setting TRUE useful reproducible workflows.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: message indicating whether data acquired already existed disk, writes data files disk specified target directory.

title: Get Works from Project Gutenberg — get_gutenberg_data
text: function retrieves Gutenberg works based specified LCC subjects optional author birth death years. checks data already exists target directory provides option overwrite . function also creates target directory exist. number works greater 1000 'confirmed' parameter set TRUE, prompts user confirmation. retrieved works filtered based public domain rights USA availability text. resulting works downloaded saved CSV file target directory. information Library Congress Classification (LCC) subjects, refer Library Congress Classification Guide.

what: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
title: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
text: function wrapper around ggsave ggplot2 package allows write ggplot object part knitr document output later use. designed used code block. file name, specified, label code block.

title: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
code: write_gg(   gg_obj = NULL,   file = NULL,   target_dir = NULL,   device = "pdf",   theme = NULL,   ... )

title: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
text: gg_obj ggplot written. specified, last ggplot created written. file name file written. specified, label code block used. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. device device used saving ggplot. Options include "pdf" (default), "png", "jpeg", "tiff", "svg". theme ggplot2 theme applied ggplot. Default theme specified ggplot2 options. ... Additional arguments passed ggsave function ggplot2 package.

title: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
text: path written file.

title: Write a ggplot object to a file — write_gg
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(ggplot2)  plot_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "plot")  # Write a ggplot object as a PDF file p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + geom_point()  write_gg(  gg_obj = p,  file = "plot_file",  target_dir = plot_dir,  device = "pdf")  unlink(plot_dir) } # }

what: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: function wrapper around save_kable kableExtra package allows write kable object part knitr document output later use. designed used code block. file name, specified, label code block.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
code: write_kbl(   kbl_obj,   file = NULL,   target_dir = NULL,   device = "pdf",   bs_theme = "bootstrap",   ... )

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: kbl_obj knitr_kable object written. file name file written. specified, name based current knitr code block label. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. device device used saving file. Options include "pdf" (default), "html", "latex", "png", "jpeg". Note Chromium-based browser (e.g., Google Chrome, Chromium, Microsoft Edge Brave) required system options except "latex'. suitable browser available, function stop return error message. bs_theme Bootstrap theme applied kable object (applicable HTML output). Default "bootstrap". ... Additional arguments passed save_kable function kableExtra package.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
text: path written file.

title: Write a kable object to a file — write_kbl
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(knitr)  table_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "table")  mtcars_kbl <- kable(  x = mtcars[1:5, ],  format = "html")  # Write a kable object as a PDF file write_kbl(  kbl_obj = mtcars_kbl,  file = "kable_pdf",  target_dir = table_dir,  device = "pdf")  # Write a kable as an HTML file with a custom Bootstrap theme write_kbl(  kbl_obj = mtcars_kbl,  file = "kable_html",  target_dir = table_dir,  device = "html",  bs_theme = "flatly")  unlink(table_dir) } # }

what: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: function wrapper around dput allows write R object part knitr document output later use. designed used code block. file name, specified, label code block. Use standard dget function read file back R session.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
code: write_obj(obj, file = NULL, target_dir = NULL, ...)

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: obj R object written. file name file written. specified, label code block used. target_dir directory file written. specified, current working directory used. ... Additional arguments passed dput.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
text: path written file.

title: Write an R object as a file — write_obj
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ obj_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "obj")  # Write a data frame as a file write_obj(  obj = mtcars,  file = "mtcars_data",  target_dir = obj_dir)  # Read the file back into an R session my_mtcars <- dget(file.path(obj_dir, "mtcars_data"))  unlink(obj_dir) } # }

title: qtkit 1.0.0
text: Adds calc_assoc_metrics() calculate association metrics two variables. Adds calc_type_metrics() calculate dispersion frequency metrics variable. Adds create_data_dictionary() create data dictionary dataset. Adds find_outliers() identify observations data frame outliers given variable. Adds get_gutenberg_data() download dataset Project Gutenberg. Adds add_pkg_to_bib() add package bibliography. write_gg() writes ggplot object file. write_kbl() writes knitr::kable object file. write_obj() writes R object file. Adds find_outliers() identify observations data frame outliers given variable. Notes: get_talkbank_data() postponed future release.

title: qtkit 0.10.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-06-24 Initial CRAN submission.
